SummarySection.Title: General Information About X Cancer
SummarySection.KeyPoint: X cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the x.
A, B, C can affect the risk of developing x cancer.
X cancer is sometimes caused by inherited gene mutations.
Possible signs of x cancer include A, B, C.

SummarySection.KeyPoint: Tests that examine the A, B, and C are used to help diagnose (find) x cancer.
SummarySection.Para: The following tests and procedures can help detect x cancer:

ItemizedList.ListItem: Biopsy: Cells, tissues, or fluid are removed for examination under a microscope to see if cancer cells are present. When only a sample of tissue is removed, the procedure is called an incisional biopsy or core biopsy. When an entire tumor or lesion is removed, the procedure is called an excisional biopsy. When a sample of tissue or fluid is removed with a needle, the procedure is called a needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration.

SummarySection.KeyPoint: Certain factors affect choice of treatment and prognosis (chance of recovery).
SummarySection.Para: The choice of treatment and prognosis (chance of recovery) depend on the stage of the cancer (whether it affects part of the X, involves the whole X, or has spread to other places in the body), the type of cancer, the size of the tumor, and the patient's general health. SummarySection.Title: Stages of x cancer
SummarySection.KeyPoint: After x cancer has been diagnosed (found), tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the X or to other parts of the body.
